ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: it does not give them any headache nor does it leave them stupefied.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: a drink by which their minds will not be clouded nor will it cause drunkenness;
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: which will not cause them any intoxication or illness.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: Their heads shall not ache with it, nor shall they lose their senses.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: They shall not be affected with headache thereby, nor shall they get exhausted,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: Wherefrom they get no aching of the head nor any madness,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: Whereby there shall be neither headiness nor will they be inebriated.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: which causes them neither headache nor stupefaction,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: No after-ache will they receive therefrom, nor will they suffer intoxication:
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: Wherefrom they will get neither any aching of the head, nor any intoxication.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: that will neither make the head throb, nor intoxicate,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: Causing them neither headache, nor intoxication.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: No headache will they have therefrom, nor will they be intoxicated -
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [56:19] wherefrom they suffer no headache nor any stupefaction (read yanzafūna or yanzifūna, [respectively derived] from nazafa or anzafa al-shāribu, ‘the drinker became inebriated’), in other words, they do not get a headache from it nor do they lose their senses, in contrast to [the case with] the wine of this world;
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: (Wherefrom they get no aching of the head) from drinking (nor any madness) nor get intoxicated; it is also said that this means, according to another reading: their drinking is continuous,
